conclusion: The v-t graph of a particle moving in a straight line is given, and the task is to determine whether the motion direction from 2 to 3 seconds is the same as or opposite to the defined positive direction.
The v-t graph shows velocity (v) on the y-axis in m·s⁻¹ versus time (t) on the x-axis in seconds.
From 1 to 2 seconds, v decreases linearly from +2 m·s⁻¹ to 0 m·s⁻¹.
From 2 to 3 seconds, v decreases linearly from 0 m·s⁻¹ to -2 m·s⁻¹.

Positive velocity (+v) indicates motion in the defined positive direction, negative velocity (-v) indicates motion in the direction opposite to the defined positive direction, and zero velocity indicates the particle is momentarily at rest.
At t = 2s, v = 0 m·s⁻¹, meaning the particle is momentarily at rest.
At t = 3s, v = -2 m·s⁻¹, meaning the particle is moving in the direction opposite to the defined positive direction.
Throughout the interval from t = 2s to t = 3s, the velocity is negative and decreasing (becoming more negative).
When velocity is negative, the particle moves in the direction opposite to the defined positive direction.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the motion direction of the particle is opposite to the defined positive direction because the velocity is negative during this time interval.
